intro: Diospyros blepharophylla, commonly known as the ghost gum or ghost gum tree, is a deciduous tree native to Australia. It belongs to the Ebenaceae family and is characterized by its smooth, pale grey bark that peels in thin layers. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers followed by edible, round fruits that are typically red or orange when mature. Its leaves are opposite, simple, and have a distinctive bluish-green color with a waxy coating. Diospyros blepharophylla is well adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a resilient and drought-tolerant species.
